Authors:
Beata Guzow-Krzemińska, Anna Łubek, Jiri Malicek, Tor
Tonsberg, Magdalena Oset, Martin Kukwa
Title:
Lecanora stanislai, a new, sterile, usnic acid containing
lichen species from Europe and North America
Keywords:
biodiversity, crustose lichens, Lecanorales, taxonomy,
sorediate lichens
Abstract:
Lecanora stainislai is characterized by very thin,
sorediate, endosubstratal in non-sorediate parts thalli (sometimes with
few small non-sorediate areoles) covered with a more or less continuous
layer of soredia and production of usnic acid and zeorin. It usually
grows on a smooth bark of trees in forests of northern Poland, Ukraine
and the Czech Republic. It is chemically similar to the sorediate L.
compallens, which however has an episubstratal thallus in non-sorediate
parts and often delimited soralia. They have also different phylogenetic
positions within the L. symmicta group. Moreover, based on molecular
markers analysis the position of L. expallens is resolved within this
group for the first time.
